overview_of_class:
The "Wiener Moderne" has over the last hundred years become a household
epoch which is indispensable in German literature curricula and has been
handily itemized and filed away in countless textbooks and introductory
works. Many buzzwords - Antinaturalismus, Empiriokritizismus,
Kaffeehausliteratur, Sprachskepsis, Psychoanalyse - have somewhat
replaced the knowledge of the actual texts, and since everybody already
seems to know what Wiener Moderne is about, the discourse about the
epoch often follows the same precast lines. In order to avoid the
oversimplifications that come with this approach, the seminar will first
and foremost serve to read works of the Wiener Moderne (many of them
canonical) as close and as impartial as possible. Another focal point is
the social history of "modernity" and the way literary innovation is
processed in contemporary media. Class taught in German.
Most of the class material will be available on Canvas or online. Two
small Reclam editions which will be used in the first weeks of the class
should be bought early enough: Arthur Schnitzler: Anatol. Anatols
Größenwahn. Der grüne Kakadu (ed. Gerhart Baumann), ISBN:
978-3-15-008399-4; Hugo von Hofmannsthal: Lyrische Dramen (ed. Andreas
Thomasberger), ISBN: 978-3-15-018038-9.
